rev.diff:
Line 181: Line 181:
In April 2004, Google received complaints that a search for "Jew" on its site listed the [[anti-Semitic]] website [[Jew Watch]] at or near the top of the list. Google responded that this was due to the content-neutrality of the PageRank algorithm, and the fact that anti-semites used the specific word "Jew" (as opposed to "Jewish" or "Judaism") more often than others. [http://www.google.com/explanation.html]
In April 2004, Google received complaints that a search for "Jew" on its site listed the [[anti-Semitic]] website [[Jew Watch]] at or near the top of the list. Google responded that this was due to the content-neutrality of the PageRank algorithm, and the fact that anti-semites used the specific word "Jew" (as opposed to "Jewish" or "Judaism") more often than others. [http://www.google.com/explanation.html]
â
As a reaction, some [[weblogger]]s launched a [[Google bomb]] to put the corresponding [[Jew|Wikipedia article]] at the top of the search results. In early January 2006, the Wikipedia ''Jew'' Article overtook ''Jew Watch'' as the number one result. However, by [[January 8]], [[2006]], the ''Jew Watch'' page had climbed back to the top.
+
As a reaction, some [[weblogger]]s launched a [[Google bomb]] to put the corresponding [[Jew|Wikipedia article]] at the top of the search results. In early January 2006, the Wikipedia ''Jew'' Article overtook ''Jew Watch'' as the number one result. By [[January 8]], [[2006]], the ''Jew Watch'' page had climbed back to the top. However, by January 29, 2006, the Wikipedia article was on top again.
There is also an option for Google account users, who are logged in, to remove offensive search results.
There is also an option for Google account users, who are logged in, to remove offensive search results.
